Introduction
About &app;
&app; is a VGA Planets client for the GNOME platform. This project's objectives are to produce a full-featured client, easy to use by new players but powerful enough for experienced VGA Planets emperors.
The final version of this program should include the basic gaming capability, plus a good pack of statistical charts, estimation tables and graphs and calculus dialogs. Also it'll have scripting support using (maybe) the Python interpreter embebbed, to allow easy and fast addition of features such as estrategical resource administration, etc.
GWP's user interface is being designed so that most activities are centered around the starchart, this way the player can keep a global vision of the territory. For the UI design I took ideas from various VGA Planets clients, such as Informer, VPA and PCC, nevertheless GWP has its own unique style, as a result of the blending of the best characteristics of such clients plus some of my own ideas (and some of my friends ideas too!).
What is VGA Planets?
For this section, I'll extract a piece of the introduction made by its creator, Tim Wisseman. You can read the whole version at http://www.vgaplanets.com/intro2.htm.
VGA Planets is a graphical, multi-player, play by electronic mail, space war game. This game simulates combat in space between galactic scale empires. The game emphasizes colonization of space and the development of the planets that you will find, colonize and/or conquer. How well you develop these resources will determine what kind of starships (freighters and capital ships) you will be able to produce and how well you will be able to defend your space and attack your neighbors.
This game is designed to be a strategic and tactical game of warfare, but you will also need to be able to build an economy and service your empire. With a well-developed economic base you will have a greater potential for winning the game.
As the leader of your empire you are responsible for all of the decisions that affect your growth and production (except, of course, being attacked by your neighbor). You will decide how to best develop your planets with the resources available to you. You will decide what type of starship(s) to be built at your starbase(s). You are the mastermind behind your race and you are in a race to see which empire can first conqueror the universe.
At the start of the game you are left with a homeworld, a low tech starbase, and two low tech starships. These are the only things left of your former empire since the nastiest Ion Storm ever recorded hit the Echo Cluster. You will need to manage your planet's population, money, minerals and other resources wisely, for these are your only sources of production early in the game. If you manage them well you will be able to quickly expand and broaden your economic and mineral base, while still keeping a wary eye on your potentially dangerous neighbors. Remember, while you are growing and becoming stronger, so are your neighbors.
VGA Planets is designed to be able to handle from two to eleven players in a play by mail (electronic mail) game format. The game is designed to be played as a Net or Bulletin Board System (BBS) game (as long as file transfers are permitted and available), although it can be played solely on one computer. Many of the Net players are playing using E-mail and UUENCODE.
Game Mechanics
The fact that VGA Planets is a play-by-email game means that is an offline kind of game, this is why the players have to follow certain steps when joining a game:
The host generates RST (result) files, one for each player.
The host send the RST files to the players (via e-mail, or any other form).
Each player receives their RST file and unpacks it with some VP client.
Each player make their actions and generate the TRN with some VP client.
The players send their TRN files to the host.
The host receives the TRN files and proccess them, check if some player is trying to cheat, and so on. Then, go back to the first step.
VP Games on the Internet
Maybe you've never played this great game and would like to give it a try, but you don't have any friends that know VGA Planets, so...how to start?
Fortunately, there are several websites dedicated to host VP games, so that you can sign up to any game and play with people all over the world. Some interesting VP hosting sites are:
The Last Domain VGA Planets
NAVGAP 'VGA Planets' Hosting Service
Sorcermon - VGA Planets Hosting
UK Gamers - VGA Planets Server
The Deep South
Planetsserver.com
Learn more about VGA Planets
&app; is just a client, so this documentation is made to teach you how to use it, but it won't teach you how to play VGA Planets, that's a little more complicated.
If you don't know how to play VP, then you should visit Donovan's Site, the best and more complete VGA Planets information site on the Internet. There you'll have all the necessary to become a great space conqueror.
The Game Manager
The game manager is an utility that &app; provides to store several game settings on a centralized fashion. As you can see on , it consists of an icon list, each icon representing a configured game.
&app;'s Game Manager
You can add a new game, delete or edit an existing game's preferences, with no danger of modifying the real data files. The game manager only register game data on the GNOME registry subsystem.
When you press the New button or edit an existing game, you'll see a dialog like the one shown at , you have to select the game directory where your game data files reside, then the program will detect the available races and will show them on the list at the left.
New/Edit Game dialog
When the available races are listed, you have to click on the one you will use to play (this allows you to have many races within the same directory, and be able to play them all), and also type the game name, that will be used on the icon list previously shown.
If the program detects that exists a RST file to be unpacked, the Unpack button will be activated so that you can execute that operation instantly.
The other fields, as of version &appversion; are not being used for anything, you can leave them blank.
&app; Basic Usage
This client is very starchart centric, almost all the operations can be done from some kind of starchart view, so that the player can maintain a global view at the game.
Starchart keystrokes
The Echo Cluster is a square of 2000 by 2000 light-years, the starchart provides the player an extra view, a margin around the Echo Cluster of 500 LY wide. It has grid, with 100 LY between lines.
The keystrokes to scroll the starchart are:
A: Scroll left
D: Scroll right
W: Scroll up
S: Scroll down
You can also scroll the starchart using the mouse, by dragging it. Also, you can toggle the grid by pressing G and zoom in and zoom out with + and - from the keypad.
The planet names are automatically hidden when you zoom out below 100%, but if you want you can turn them off using the Planet names entry on the View menu. Similar actions you can make with minefields and ion storms.
Planet operations
Each planet is represented by a tiny circle, if it's grey the planet is unknown, if it's green, the planet is ours. Planets with a green halo, are planets that have starbases orbiting, so that you can identify them quickly.
&app;'s StarChart
As you can see on , when you click on a planet, a little red mark is placed around the selected planet and the most important data about that planet appears on the bar at the right. The idea of this is that you have only the important data with a fast, single-click on each planet. If you want more detailed information about the planet, just double-click on one, and two extra panels will appear, like the ones on
At this mode, you can see all the data about the selected planet, and the starchart centers around the selected planet so you can see it sorroundings. You should note that the starchart scrolling functions are disabled in this view mode, you can return to full starchart view hitting the Esc key, or double-clicking on the planet again.
On the lower left panel, there's a table with planet's future information, based on its actual state, this is very useful to establish long term strategies, this panel is intended to contain more and more of this type of charts, graphs, etc.
Detailed information about a planet
Starbase operations
Inside the planet extended view, you have on the upper right corner the possibility to change to starbase view, there you'll have all the needed information about the actual starbase, asi you can see on the picture below.
Information about a starbase
On future releases, the lower left panel will have several charts about the starbase providing you lots of valuable information.
If the planet has no starbase, the corresponding information fields are obviously erased.
Starship operations
Ships on starchart are shown as little triangles, they're blue if the ships are our own, and red if not. This triangles are oriented specially to show the actual ship's heading, so you can be aware of that even without the need of selecting every ship.
To select a ship you should right-click near it, the right panel switches to ship list mode, and show a complete list of every visible ship on the same spot, similarly to , drawing a green mark around the selected location.
Ship list view
On the list you'll see the ship's ID and name, and selecting any of this list items will update the information below, showing a limited but vital set of ship data. If you double-right-click on the starchart, or double-click on the ship list, the extra panels will appear showing the rest of the ship's data and the corresponding ship image, just like .
